source.80cd7944:
import numpy  as np
import pandas as pd

# To use this experimental feature, we need to explicitly ask for it:
from sklearn.experimental import enable_hist_gradient_boosting
from sklearn.ensemble     import HistGradientBoostingRegressor

train_data = pd.read_csv('../input/tabular-playground-series-jan-2021/train.csv',index_col=0)
test_data  = pd.read_csv('../input/tabular-playground-series-jan-2021/test.csv', index_col=0)
sample     = pd.read_csv('../input/tabular-playground-series-jan-2021/sample_submission.csv')

X_train = train_data.iloc[:,:-1]
y_train = train_data['target']

regressor  =  HistGradientBoostingRegressor()
regressor.fit(X_train, y_train)

sample.iloc[:,1:] = regressor.predict(test_data)
sample.to_csv('submission.csv',index=False)
source.9e95ac0d:
## [Tabular Playground Series](https://www.kaggle.com/c/tabular-playground-series-jan-2021): A histogram gradient boost regressor minimalist starter script

Here is a very simple starter script that uses the (still experimental) [histogram-based gradient boosting regression tree estimator](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.ensemble.HistGradientBoostingRegressor.html) from [scikit-learn](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/index.html).
